name: Utrecht
fun_fact: Fun fact: Utrecht's canals are unique in the world with their two-tier wharf system! Built in the 13th century, these canal-side cellars once stored goods unloaded directly from boats. Today, they've been transformed into cozy waterfront restaurants and caf√©s, creating a double-level canal experience found nowhere else - not even in Amsterdam.

hero_dishes.name: Broodje Mario
hero_dishes.description: Utrecht's legendary sandwich - a crispy, fluffy bread roll stuffed with salami, chorizo, cheese, pickled vegetables, and peppers. The bread is perfectly crisp on the outside, fluffy inside.
hero_dishes.origin_story: A local institution that has become synonymous with Utrecht street food. Mario's sandwich shop has been serving this iconic combination for decades, attracting locals and food pilgrims alike.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Broodje Mario sandwich shop - prepare for lines, but locals say it's worth the wait

hero_dishes.name: Modern Dutch Cuisine at LOOF
hero_dishes.description: Contemporary Dutch dishes crafted with local, seasonal ingredients. The menu changes frequently to showcase the best of regional produce prepared with modern techniques.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Part of Utrecht's movement to elevate traditional Dutch cooking beyond stereotypes, focusing on farm-to-table philosophy.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Restaurant LOOF - known for passion and local ingredient sourcing

hero_dishes.name: Surinamese Roti and Bara
hero_dishes.description: Flavorful Surinamese flatbread curry wraps and fried bara bread - legacy of Surinamese immigration to Netherlands after 1975 independence. Rich curried fillings with potatoes, chicken, or vegetables.
hero_dishes.origin_story: When Suriname gained independence in 1975, many Surinamese relocated to the Netherlands, bringing their vibrant food culture. Utrecht became a hub for authentic Surinamese cuisine.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Pappje Him's - authentic Surinamese restaurant selling broodjes, bara, and roti

hero_dishes.name: Indonesian Rijsttafel
hero_dishes.description: Dutch-Indonesian fusion meal featuring multiple small dishes served with rice - a colonial legacy that has become quintessentially Dutch dining.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Reflects the Netherlands' colonial history with Indonesia, now a beloved part of Dutch food culture.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Indonesian Restaurant Blauw - highly recommended by locals

signature_drinks.name: Maximus Pandor
signature_drinks.description: Bitter blond beer brewed locally in Utrecht. Clean, hoppy, and refreshing with a distinctive bitter finish.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Enjoyed in canal-side wharf cellar pubs and local bars. Utrecht locals take pride in their hometown beer.

signature_drinks.name: Dutch Coffee
signature_drinks.description: Strong filter coffee, often enjoyed with stroopwafels or pastries at canal-side caf√©s.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Leisurely morning or afternoon ritual at one of Utrecht's many cozy caf√©s overlooking the two-tier canals.

food_culture_notes: Utrecht's food scene is far more diverse than expected - Surinamese, Indonesian, West African, and modern Dutch cuisines coexist
The unique wharf cellars along canals have been repurposed into cozy waterfront restaurants with unbeatable atmosphere
Kantien restaurant loves everything typically Dutch - monthly changing menu with organic ingredients from the neighborhood
University town energy brings trendy caf√©s and international food markets
Dutch eating culture emphasizes gezelligheid (cozy conviviality) - long meals with friends by candlelight
Market culture thrives - fresh seafood, artisan cheeses, and local produce available at vibrant food markets
Unlike Amsterdam's tourist-heavy dining, Utrecht retains authentic local food traditions
